div.head: TO THE READER.
div.p:
TIS now about 14 years ince I laboured under an extraordinary pain in both my knees and feet, not knowing whither to turn my elf for pain, having ued in vain all thoe means by which I formerly had found ome eae. After I had paed five or ix weeks in thoe exceive pains, which ometimes, in pight of my teeth, extorted tears from my eyes, and conumed my fleh as well as my trength, keeping me in a manner always leeples; I was perwaded to uffer an Indian Doctres to come to me, which was of Quinam, (whom my Wife commonly employed for the curing of our laves, and who alo had been very uccesful in recovering my only
daughter from a certain difficulty of breathing he had been troubled with for two years together). This Indian woman being demanded, whether he knew how to cure that painful dieae which I was moleted with; Anwered, he did. But to tell you the truth, it was done by a way of Burning: Which means being by me rejected out of an apprehenion I had of
<> pain that mut needs accompany uch a remedy; he aid, that then he would prepare omething to mitigate the pains I uffered, and bring me uch a medicine in the afternoon; repeating till, that if I would endure the Cautick or Burning remedy, the pain hould ever after tay away: But, for all that, I could not then reolve upon it.

The woman being gone, upon further conideration, I began to repent that I had refued the ue of her Cautick; and thought with my elf, that however this propoed remedy hould operate, I could feel but one pain at a time, either that of the Gout, or that
of the Cautick; longing to ee my Doctres again; who being returned, and asked, whether he had ready her matter for the Cautick, anwered miling, he had: At the ame time drawing it forth out of her pocket, and deiring me that I would uffer her to try her art and skill upon me; which having at lat agreed unto, he went preently to work; having demanded a lighted candle, and olicitouly earch'd for that part of the place affected where the greatet pain was: And thereupon he burned with her Moxa (of which hereafter) on my feet and knees, (to my bet remembrance) about twenty little Ecars, which looked like little gray pecks, without raiing any bliters, or cauing any after-pain; whereupon alo all the pain of the Gout vanih'd. All this operation was finihed within les than half an hour, without any bodies hearing me complain of pain. And I herewith declare, that even whilt the burning lated, I found my elf much inclined to leep; and that in uch a manner,
that after the operation was over, I was o overcome by leep, that I lept very quietly near 24 hours together, without ever waking; whereas afore, by reaon of the cruel pains. I had not been able to leep at all for everal days and nights together. Being awakened, I found, 'tis true, my feet and knees yet much welled; but in a few days after I was alo freed from thoe tumifying humours, by the little openings made by the ame Cautick, o that I was able to return to the work of my vocation; mot heartily thanking God Almighty for his goodnes to me, and duly acknowledging the operation of this Indian woman, admiring withal the powerfulnes of this remedy againt o contumacious an evil, as is the Gout. There near paed full 27 months e're I heard any thing of a Gouty pain, and I began to be full of hope it would for ever have forgot and quitted me, according to the promie of my Doctres; which not long after, to my great orrow, died. True it is, that after the time named, I had once, or at mot
twice in one year ome grudgings of that dieae; but never any ore fit: Only about four years ago, when I fell into a very hot Fever of nine days continuance, without hope of life, that Fever changed, and ended in the Gout; all the pains of which, in a very hort time, I freed my elf from, by means of the aid Cautick; o that I protet candidly, that being now in a Fever again, I long as much and more for a fit of the Gout, as I formerly was wont to dread it; knowing it to be an argument of the trength of the heart, when a Fever determines in the Gout: pon which core the famous Crato, Phyitian to three Emperors, and the learned Sennertus, were wont to comfort Gouty men, by telling them that this evil tended to health.

Now, from the day that I was o oon and with o light pains cured of the Gout, I have given my thoughts liberty to expatiate upon the nature of the Gout: And firt of all, to call in quetion, whether Phyitians hitherto have had a right notion, and given a
true account of the nature and qualities of this dieae: And after a regorous enquiry into the matter, and upon the conideration of this overeign remedy, I concluded, that this dieae mut needs have another immediate or proximate caue, eat, &c. than had been hitherto by any man clearly explained and proved.

Whereupon I thought good to dicover to the world my thoughts of this whole matter, although at firt I intended to have kept them only for my bet friends and nearet relations. I think, I have herein detected ome things for the improvement of Phyick, and for the relief of thoe that are ubject to this dieae, which ele is by mot men exclaimed againt as incurable; and does o disfigure many a comely peron, that he eems not to be the ame he was before. In the doing whereof, my deign is to do good to my fellow-creatures, and to lay out this talent for their eae and comfort; as alo to open a way for intelligent and tudious men to earch into, and
find out the nature not only of the Gout, but alo of divers other dieaes that have any affinity therewith; uch as are Head-pains, Tooth-ach, Pleuriies, Colick, and even the Falling-icknes it elf. As I hall be able, in time, if God vouchafe me life, more clearly to make out; epecially, if the truth here delivered be embraced, and this mall work encouraged, and the remedy here recommended put in practice; which I heartily wih may be done according to my precript, before it be prejudged, and rejected.

div.head: THE GOUT, More narrowly SEARCHT, and FOUND out; Together with The certain CURE thereof.
CHAP. I.
Of the Gout, and what it is.
div.p:
Theoph. I Have undertood with joy, Theodidactus, that you have a ingular opinion of the Gout, its Caue, Seat, Paages and Ways; as alo, that you know the true and genuine Remedy againt this cruel Dieae, which is alo come to your door, no les than
it had aaulted your Father and Father-in-Law, who were o grievouly tormented therewith, that they became altogether helples, and were o pent and conumed thereby, that before they arrived to any coniderable old age, they fell into their graves. Whereas I ee you, to admiration, advanced to o great an age, and in o much vigour, as if you had never known or had any Podagrical peron in your Family, or among your Relations, or had never been ubject your elf to that merciles dieae. Hence it is, that I mot heartily intreat you, that you would be pleaed to explain this matter to me, according to the good inclinations, which I have always perceived in you, of doing good to your Neighbour.

Theodid. My dear Theophilus, although in doing this I tep omewhat out of my Vocation; yet Chritian charity contrains me to comply with your deires herein, and 10 to confine this knowledg of mine to my particular Friends and Relations; on condition
only, that at this time you do ask me no more quetions, than what hall be pertinent to make us come to the knowledg of the Gout and the Remedy thereof.
Theoph. I mot kindly thank you for your goodnes, and promie you to contain my elf within the bounds precribed.
Theodid. Very well; be pleaed therefore to propoe your quetions in that order, and I hall anwer you to the bet of my knowledg.
Theoph. To recover gouty perons, and to free them from their pains (without which all the bleings of this life are inignificant,) what is above all things neceary?
Anw. To have a thorow knowledg of the Dieae and of the true Remedy thereof; both which are equally neceary, inomuch that the one without the other is not valuable.
Quet. Why is it, that for accomplihing a happy Cure, there is firt of all required a well-grounded knowledg of the Dieae?

An. Becaue 'tis impoible to cure a dieae according to Art, if the nature thereof be hid from the Artit: And the want of this is the chief reaon, why the care and pains taken by o many learned Phyitians hath proved o ineffectual in the Gout.
Qu. What then are the Requiites to attain to the true knowledg of this Dieae?
An. There is required a olid knowledg of thee following particulars:
1. Of the next and ever-concomitant Caue of the Gout.
2. Of the Seat of this Evil.
3. Of the Part affected.
4. Of the Ways and Paages, through which this Evil takes its coure.
5. What are the ineparable igns thereof?
6. What Symptoms commonly accompany it?
7. That the Symptoms of this Dieae be rightly ditinguihed.

If you err not in thee main points,
you are in the right way of arriving to a happy cure of this Malady.
Qu. Do you undertand by the name of Gout, all pain in the Limbs?
An. No; but that pain which in harpnes and fiercenes exceeds all other, and that which I mean to decribe.
Qu. To let pas the name of the Gout, pray give me a full and plain decription of the Dieae it elf?

An. The Gout is a preternatural, inward, deep-lurking, and for the mot part inviible little welling within in the periotium, that is, the membrane that enwraps all Bones; caued from a dry and cold ill-natured damp or vapor, which out of the arteries, by the expelling vertue of the heart, is driven out into the place that is between the bone and the periotium, for the mot part into uch Limbs of the Body as are about the Joints; in which this vapor being and remaining impacted and incloed, and ditending that mot enible membrane, produces thoe violent and intolerable
pains, whereby the motion of thoe Limbs is incumbred and dipoiled, and many other grievous accidents occaioned.
Qu. Doth this decription differ much from that which hath been hitherto delivered of this Dieae?
An. It doth: Whence it is, that I exceedingly apprehend, I hall incur harp cenures from many.

Qu. But let this pas; let us weigh rather your decription in its principal parts. And, Firt, I do remember, that you make the Gout to be a preternatural welling; whereby you doubtles imply, that the Gout is a Dieae wherein violence is done to nature in ome part or other of the Body. But this is a novelty to me, that you add, viz. that it is an inward deeplurking, and for the mot part inviible little welling, and that that welling is caued by a damp, &c. intreating you, that you would vouchafe to expres this more plain, and to render reaons thereof. And firt, why you call it an internal and deeplurking tumor?

An. The better to ditinguih it from other windy wellings, in repect of its eat: For, whereas thoe other lye between the fleh and skin, this lies deep, underneath the membrane that covers the bone; as hereafter hall be more largely proved.
Qu. But why do you add, that it is a little and motly inviible welling?
An. Becaue it is o indeed.
Qu. But pray, Sir, take care that you run not againt ene, out of a blind zeal of producing a novelty. For, is not the tumor which manifets it elf in the Gout, big and conpicuous enough?

An. You do not ditinguih between the Dieae it elf and the Symtom, which is the tumbling tone of many even learn'd men. And the want of this very ditinction eems to me to have been the main, if not the only obtacle, why they have not lighted upon the true caue of the Gout, and why they have taken quid pro quo?
Qu. What then is to be done, not to mitake herein?

An. You mut ever make a difference between the welling, which is caued by the morbific gouty matter, and that which is conequent to the Gout; and this is to be laid as a fundamental Truth, never to be remov'd, viz. That the humour, which makes the external palpable and viible welling in the Gout, is not the Gout or dolorifique matter. Which are not o much my words, as the words of that famous Phyitian of Dort, called John Van Beverwyck, deliver'd by him in his Book of the Gout, and which he hath borrow'd out of the decription of that dieae, which that learned and experienced Profeor of Phyick at Wittenberg, Daniel Sennertus, left behind him. Which alo is the reaon that I hall place that aqueous and erous tumor amongt the ymptoms of the Gout; where alo it is to be handled, and not here, where we peak of the Dieae it elf.
Qu. What, is not the humor, that caues the outward and viible welling, the Gout or dolorific matter?
A. No, they differ very much from one another, and may be ufficiently ditinguiht by thoe that will attentively conider.
Qu. Wherein conits this difference?

An. In this, that the one is the caue of the Dieae, the other a ymptom; which will be made very clear, when we hall come to treat of this ymptom. But in part to atisfie your curioity, pray mark the ratiocination of the lately named Beverwyck, aying in the quoted Book: That the humour which makes the welling, is not properly the peccant matter, is from hence evident; becaue that in the beginning, before the part wells, the greatet pain is felt, and the ame grows les, when the welling appears. 'Tis true, that that learned man adhereth till to the opinion of the altih Serum, affirming that it is a erous humor, pervaded by a alin acrimony,
that caues the Gout. But herein he, as well as the great Sennertus, hath mitaken. Mean time, tis certain, that the external tumor is not the morbid matter it elf, for the reaon given; and, which is more, ome podagrical perons endure great pain, without the appearance of any viible welling.

div.head: CHAP. II.
Of the inward Tumour of the Gout, and how it is motly inviible.
div.p: Qu. I Shall for the preent ret contented with the proof alledged, until we come to the ymptoms: But, when this ymptomatical or accidental welling of the Gout is preent, do you then oberve two orts of welling in this Dieae, one inward, the other outward?
An. I do o; of which two, the firt is that which I ay in the decription to be a welling that is little, and for the mot part inviible?
Qu. Why do you ay o?

An. Becaue it is indeed mall, and for the mot part cannot be een by the harpet eye of the body, though it be een by the eye of reaon. For, although you outwardly perceive no welling, you may not thence infer, that there lurks none within, foramuch as the contrary is true in thee and other wellings. See the proof hereof in a couple of obervations of the skilful Phyitian and Chirurgian Hildanus in his econd Part, the 37th. and 38th. concerning dangerous and deperate tumors in the mucles of the tomach, in which nothing preternatural of welling, or other diorder could be een outwardly.
Qu. If this tumor cannot be perceived by the eye, whence do you then know that there is an inward one?
An. From the violent, pungent, beating, ditending, and continual pain, to be eaily perceived by ones finger.

Qu. But, it eems, by what you intimate
in the decription of the Gout, that ometimes this tumor may be een?

An. Yes, it may; for at times it appears plainly enough, though few Artits take it for a gouty welling, miled by the external appearance of it, which is in the form of a mall hard pimple on the place of the part affected; of which you have a manifet proof in Pareus, the French Chirurgian, treating of a ditemper in a young woman at Bourdeaux, that had uch a tumor on her thigh; though Pareus doth not record it for uch.
Qu. When may this tumor be perceived by the eye?

An. Then chiefly, when the gouty caue attacks the Patient, not about the joints of the limbs, but in or about the middle of thoe places, with a boyling pain, wherein nature labours as much as he can (though he be not trong enough) to expel the peccant matter. At which time, if you oberve it carefully, ome tumor appears,
as was aid above. This I have found not only in my elf, but very notably in another, that was a young man, employed here in the Foundery of Batavia, called Martyn Smith of Brelaw, who having the Gout in his right foot, without a coniderable afflux of humors, the evil etled on the midt of his foot, in the form of a protuberant hard pimple or button: Which I alo, by the help of God, did preently cure, o that he the ame hour, without any pain, went out of the houe to his Work-houe, which can be atteted by the Phyitian Thomas Flory, and the chief Chirurgian Warner Leuretius, as eye-witnees, that aw it with great admiration.

div.head: CHAP. III
Of the next and always concomitant Caue of the Gout
div.p:
Qu. A After you have ufficiently made out, that the gouty
matter caues a welling, for the mot part inviible; be pleaed to explain to us what is the next and always accompanying caue of this tumour; which to know, I think to be of great importance.

An. You judg aright; foramuch as the Cure hath always a repect to the Caue of the dieae; and ince 'tis in vain to hope for a recovery, as long as there is an error or mitake about the peccant or gouty matter.
Qu. Have Phyitians been of one opinion herein?

An. No: For ome have aigned the caue to be a limy and cold humor; ome, a mixture of gall and lime; ome, a crude, indigeted and impure blood; others, a erous humidity, mix'd with an acrimonious altnes; others, winds, with a mixture of the four known humours; others, ill-conditioned winds alone.
Qu. Whence, I pray, arieth this great diverity of opinions?

An. From thence only, that (as hath been already intimated) they
have not ditinguih'd the Gout from its ymptoms; which hath o abued them with the notion of the humors, that they have put thoe out of the lit of gouty perons, who in their Gout perceived no afflux of humors, abolutely requiring the ame in this dieae; notwithtanding that uch as find no erous welling in their gouty ditemper, do feel full as much pain as others that are wont to find that afflux, whoe grievous pains alo are coniderably abated upon the welling.
Qu. Which then is, in your judgment, the next and immediat Caue?
An. We have expreed it in our above-recited decription of the Gout, to wit, that it is a Vapor or Damp, dry and cold, and mixed with malignity.
Qu. But many will look upon this as an airy and windy fancy, and no olid truth.

An. If men hall devet themelves of prejudice, and maturely conider all what hath been aid, and is yet to
follow; I hall then expect a more favourable judgment, and an unanimous conent to my doctrine.
Qu. According to your theory, the Gout is to be reckoned among Windy wellings?
An. So it mut be, becaue grounded upon experience, the Mitres of Fools.
Qu. But is not this a quite new opinion; or hath there ever been any learned man that hath delivered the ame?

An. When I lately enumerated unto you the various opinions concerning the caue of the Gout, you may remember, that the lat of them was that which placeth it in meer winds, Now, among thoe Doctors, Sennertus reckons Guainerius and Matthaeus de Gradibus, two eminent Phyitians; and, as far as I can find, the Chinee Doctors are all of that mind. Beides, that ancient Phyitian, Guido de Culiaca (though in the Gout he follows the Humorits) relates, that he had read in ome precriptions of
health given to the Popes of Rome, that this dieae did arie from winds; and the Royal Chirurgian Pareus, p. 534. aigns, for the certain caue of the running Gout, a very thin fuliginous matter, which is nothing ele but a ubtile moaky damp, or pirituous ubtance.
Qu. But Pareus doth not peak o of the other kind of Gout.

An. 'Tis true, that he affirms it of the running Gout; but then I mut ay, that that kind doth not at all in its eence, or next caue, differ from the other Gout, but only in ome qualities, relating to the thinnes and thicknes of damps; thoe, from whence proceeds the running Gout, thinner and ubtler; and thoe which caue the other Gout, courer and thicker. And 'tis notorious, that almot all intelligent Phyitians aign damps for the next caue of Toothaches, Head-aches, Pleuriies (at leat batard Pleuriies), Colicks, and Epilepies: Dieaes which in name indeed, place, and ome ymptoms, differ
from the Gout, but not in their true eence; they being o near a-kin to one another, that they acknowledg but one and ame caue.

Qu. 'Tis true, that ome learned men have affirmed, winds or damps to be the next caue of the Gout; but others have rejected that opinion, and for their ground of doing o, I hall produce but one argument for all, which M. Beverwyck alledgeth out of Sennertus in his Treatie of the Gout, aying, All icknees which arie from winds, do not lat o long as the Gout; and making ue of this reaon for his denying the flatus or winds to be the true Caue of the Gout. And further in his Medicina, p. 62. treating of Tumors in general, he declares, That the windy wellings do vanih eaiet of all. What you can ay to this objection, I long to hear.

An. Thoe great men peak here only in general of windy tumors; and what they ay is only true of uch windy wellings as lurk under the
skin, or in flehy parts; not in thoe that lie in deep parts, and under firm and thick membranes, as in the Gout, and other hidden or manifet wellings, raied from latent winds: See the proof hereof in Hildanus, p. 6. ob. 40. in a Tympanites that was refractory to all remedies.
Qu. What then is the true caue why the Gout is o long a curing? Is the gouty caue (the damp) o difficult to be with peed removed and evaporated?

An. The gouty damp is eay enough to be evacuated, and 'tis even forward to be exhaled; but there is a notable obtacle which hinders the peedy performance of it. And that is this; The impacted and incloed damp, which caueth the windy tumor in the Gout, eeks a paage to iue out at, but finds none; partly becaue of the grones of the damp; partly and chiefly by reaon of the cloe and firm membrane of the bone, under which it lurks; epecially ince the place, in which this cold damp
lodgeth, enjoys but little warmth, for the attenuating of this gros damp, and expelling it through the mall pores of that membrane.
Qu. But, I pray, Sir, let me know what is the chief motive that hath induced you to make Damps the only next caue of the Gout?

An. Firt, This remedy which I here offer, as that which uddenly cures this dieae: For, if it be true, that the Medicine declares the Dieae, as Phyitians afirm with their Mater Hippocrates; I mut then conclude, that no humors, but only a Spirituous thing, is the caue of this Dieae. Secondly, oberving the udden motion of the gouty matter, ometimes dilodging in a very hort time from one limb to another, from the hand to the foot, from one foot to the other, &c. flying as 'twere with wift wings from above to beneath, and back again; I find my elf obliged to judg, that thee are not Humors, but ome Spirituous matter able to do uch things.

div.head: CHAP. IV.
Of the Qualities of the damps that caue the Gout.
div.p: Qu. OF what quality, I pray, are thee gouty Damps?
An. The above-recited decription aith, that they are dry, cold, and illconditioned.
Qu. Why do you ay they are dry?
An. The better to ditinguih thee Damps from windy Humors.
Qu. Why cold? Is there not a hot as well as a cold Gout?

An. As there is but one next caue, which for quality is always cold; o is the ditinction of a hot and cold Gout, vain: My opinion agreeing with that of Fernelius, that all Gout aries from a cold caue.
Qu. But with what reaons can you maintain this opinion?

An. Irrefragably by the remedy it elf; as alo by the pruriency and
hivering which gouty perons, upon the motion of this cold damp, do commonly feel, epecially in thoe parts through which it takes its coure; as alo happens in Epilepies, Pleuriies, Colick, and the like, that come from cold damps.

Qu. But oft and fair: Your lat proof taken from hivering doth not hold, as Beverwyck objects; for then hould the matter of hot Fevers be alo cold, which paing through parts endowed with the ene of feeling, not only caue hivering, but alo clahing of teeth.

An. This is not aid from wellgrounded knowledg; ince it hath never yet (that I know) been atisfactorily proved, that Hot Fevers (as they are called) mut needs procced from an hot caue; and upon a thorough diquiition, it might perhaps be found, that they have been produced from ome cold matter or other; which I think at leat to be half proved, becaue ometimes an hot Fever ends in the Gout; as I have found;
not to go far, in my elf, when I was in the 50 th. year of my age. It ometimes alo comes to pas, that the Gout determines in an hot Fever; as appears from what Beverwyck aith in his Book of the Gout, p. 110. peaking of the ways through which the gouty matter takes its coure. The damp, aith he, turns back into the veins, and acends up again to the noble part (meaning the heart,) where it raies hot Fevers, Anguih, and the like evils; or hoots uddenly into ome other limb, whereby the pain that is in the hand, is oon after felt in the foot.
Qu. But is not that notable inflammation, which is often een and felt in the Gout, ufficient proof that there is a ort of Gout which comes from heat?

An. This is a Symptom or accident in the Gout, which is not caued by the next and always accompanying caue of it, but by the violent pain; as I hall more clearly make out, when I come to peak of this Symptom;
But 'tis a Symptom, (not to pas that by in this place) which hath trangely miled thoe who have mitaken it for a mark of the Gout, as Sennertus and others do ackuowledg.
Qu. Is this damp alo ill-conditioned and malignant?

An. So 'tis judged by coniderable and experienced men, as well as by my elf, and that from the intolerable pain and other accidents. So doth that old Mater Guido de Culiaco; and Pareus in his 7th. Book, ch. 2. proves it by two Examples; and our new Medicine confirms the ame. Beides, the foetid damps of the Gout do plainly peak this malignity, which is perceived both at the time of the act of burning, and after it; that being uch, that ometimes both the Patient, and the Peron that adminiters the Cautick, and drees the part, are ready to fall away. And this is mot of all found at the dreing of the little wounds, when they begin to omit good tore of moiture. For as oon as you hall in a morning open the
little Plaiters, you will be o truck with a trange tinking mell, that it will almot cat you into a wound. 'Tis very probable, that this tuff is already malign before it be cat out from the heart into the limbs; yet remaining for a while wedged in the limbs, from the evaporation obtructed, its malignity is heightned. Hence it is not adviable, to erve this burning or dreing upon any one that is fating; but 'tis bet, that both the Patient and the Agent hould firt breakfat, and take a cordial.
Qu. But, is it poible for Winds to occaion o much michief?

An. Very poible; and then epecially, when they are more peccant by their quality than quantity: So Hippocrates in his golden Tract of Flatus's doth not without caue judg of winds, that mot of all the grievous and dangerous Dieaes owe their original to them.
Qu. But can Winds breed uch viclent pain?

An. They can; chiefly when the
membranes (the main intrument of the ene of Feeling) are by them attacked and ditended.

div.head: CHAP. V.
Of the Part affected, and Seat of the Gouty matter.
div.p: Qu. WHich then, in this painful Dieae, is the part that is attacked and offended by thee Winds?
An. Principally, if not only, that enible membrane called the periotium, that is, that membrane which immediatly covers the bones.
Qu. Do you not think, that the membranous ligaments do alo uffer here, or rather the membranes of the ligaments?
An. No; but I agree herein with Galen, that they have no feeling; the which is alo confirm'd by the learned Barbette in his Praxis, chap. 5. p. 30.
Qu. What do you undertand by the Peri-otium?
An. That ingle membrane or film, whereby the Author of Nature hath outwardly inveted and covered all the bones of our body, and which is a cloe and firm ubtance, extendible, and very enible.
Qu. Doth the gouty matter fall from without upon this enible periotium, fretting and biting it by its acrimony?
An. Not o; for then it could not caue o intolerable a pain, or the right Gout.
Qu. Where then are we to look for the true eat of the gouty matter?
An. No-where ele but between the membrane and the bone.
Qu. Wherein then conits the genuine eence of this Dieae?
An. In the violent ditenion or tretching of this enible membrane by the Winds, whereby this membrane being forced out of its due and natural form and ituation, excites o violent a pain.
Qu. Whence do you infer that the gouty matter lies o deep, and particularly between the membrane and the bone it elf?

An. Not only from the ditending pain, (which is to me proof ufficient) but alo from the contumaciounes of the Gout, which made Hippocrates ay in his 6th. Book, aph. 49. That the Gouty fit doth not ceae before the fortieth day. And truly, whereas all other windy tumors, that are not lodged o deep, are in a hort time made to evaporte; this windy welling of the Gout lying o deep, and lurking under o firm and cloe a membrane, (and beides, in a place of little warmth, and it elf coming from a cold caue) cannot be eaily brought to a quick evaporation, but by uch a kind of remedy as ours is.
Qu. Have not the old and new Maters mitaken the Part affected, and the true Seat of the Gout?

An. Certainly they have: For, (to peak of the part affected, and the eat together,) I mut firt alledge the
opinion of Galen, (as 'tis cited by Beverwyck;) he affirming, that the gouty moiture doth flow into the hollow of the joynts, and there forces aunder the bones; whereby the ligaments and membranes, that faten them together, are o violently expanded, that they caue that exceive pain.
Qu. Hath this entiment of the great Galen been generally judged and received to be conform to truth?
An. It hath been rejected by many, as by Beverwyck and others; and by others maintained.
Qu. Where do thoe that contradict Galen, find the Part affected, and the Seat?
An. In the ligaments and membranes that tye the bones together, being penetrated and ouzed thorough by a harp humor.
Qu. What hath moved thoe that are of the later opinion, to reject Galen's Doctrine?
An. See and read Beverwyck and others.
Qu. But how doth Galen refute their opinion, who ay, that the gouty matter ouzeth thorough the ligaments and membranes?
An. Thus, that never a gouty peron hath been perceived to have convulions or drawings of the limbs: Which yet mut needs happen, if the warm humor did pas through the ligaments and membranes.

Qu. But thee alledge, to trengthen their opinion; Firt, that the pain, as oon as the limb is but touched, preently increaeth. Secondly, the debility and troubleome motion of the part. Latly, the laxity of the ligaments, which being ouzed thorough by the humor, do tretch, and ometimes caue dilocation, Are not thee olid reaons to perwade you and all others that they have hit right?

An. Not at all; for their proof is lame in all its parts. And, not to repeat the irrefragable proof of Galen againt their opinion, the pain doth not increae when the limb is but touch'd and moved, becaue, forooth!
the gouty matter hath ouzed through the ligaments and membranes: No; for, not thee, but the periotium is the part affected in this evil, which being by the gouty damp already ditended, is upon the touching, or leat motion of the limb, irritated a new, and o caueth new pain. Where I etablih this for a certain truth, that never the gouty matter, but only the accidental affluxed humor ouzeth through the ligaments, o as to occaion tretching and dilocation: Which we intend more fully to make out, when we come to peak of this accident of dilocation.

Qu. But againt Galen's proof, the defenders of this opinion alledge, that 'tis no trange thing, that the acrimonious humor of the Gout ouzing through the ligaments of the joynts, caueth no drawing in the limbs, becaue ay they, the nerves themelves are not offended, but only the membranes and membranous ligaments, which do not caue the motion; and that therefore, although they
are eized with great pain, they caue no convulion; jut as 'tis alo found in the Tooth-ach, Pleuriie, and Colick.
An. This is an exception that concludes nothing, foramuch as the Gouty matter provokes not the organs of Motion, but thoe of Sene.

div.head: CHAP. VI.
That the Gout is a general Dieae of the limbs, receiving its denomination from that limb which it eizes on; together with the place in which the Gouty matter is bred.
div.p: Qu. IS the Gout a general Dieae, (as Galen affirms) attacking all the joynts of the limbs of the body?

An. It is o general, that not one external part of any limb of the whole body is by its own nature exempt from it. The reaon is, becaue that all parts and limbs are wrapped
about with this enible membrane, called Periotium, the head, neck, jaw-bones, bret, back, and the teeth themelves, foramuch as they are incloed in their groves or pits.
Qu. Doth this Dieae take different names, according to the limb which it infets?

An. It doth o: Hence 'tis called Podagra, when it falls upon the feet; Gonagra, when upon the knees; Chiragra, when upon the hands; Ichiatica, when upon the hips: And o, the Tooth-ach, when upon the teeth; the Pleuriie, when upon the skin that clothes the ribs, &c. All which I eteem to proceed from one and the ame caue; though many will think this trange.
Qu. What is the antecedent caue of the Gout?
An. Whatoever breeds thee damps.
Qu. In what place grows this damp, being the next caue of the Gout?

An. The learned do as little agree in this, as they do in the next caue
it elf; and Fernelius complains, that no man had thoroughly earched into this point, and that through the want of the knowledg thereof, the Gout had been left for incurable.

Qu. Is this peccant matter bred only in the head, excepting the skull, as Fernelius would have it; or without the brain, as others think; or mot of all in the Vicera, as the tomach, pleen, liver, gall, and the ret?
An. I give my voice for thoe that affirm the lat, viz. that thee Gouty damps are motly generated in the inner parts, yet not excepting the head.
Qu. But can you tell, Sir, in what manner they are there produced?
An. Doubtles they are, through want of heat, gathered and laid up in ome or other of the aforementioned parts from corrupted humors, and particularly from corrupted blood.

div.head: CHAP. VII.
How, and through which ways, the Gouty matter comes to the Limbs.
div.p: Qu. SInce thee morbid damps do caue uch grievous pains in the external limbs, but are bred in the inner parts; by what means and paages do they come to thoe limbs?
An. By means of the Circulation of the blood through the manifet ways of veins and arteries.
Qu. Do not thee damps acend or decend directly into the limbs, without paing the heart?
An. They mut needs firt pas into the heart.
Qu. By what ways?
An. Through the veins, which, gathering out of the inner parts the generated damps, carry them, together with the not yet ufficiently concocted blood, into the heart.

Qu. But do not thee malign damps offend that noble part, eeing they
caue uch grievous pains in the limbs?
An. Certainly they do; and are the caue of Fevers, beating of the heart, and other ditempers; and frequently caue death, when the heart wants trength and vigor to expel them.

div.head: CHAP. VIII.
Of the Expelling Part.
div.p: Qu. IS the heart then the only trong expelling part, which drives thoe damps into the limbs?

An. It is, as is evinced by the trong motion and beating of the arteries in the Gout; whereby the heart labours to deliver it elf from uch a pernicious damp, and to dicharge and purifie the nourihing blood of the ame.
Qu. Through what ways doth the heart drive out thee damps into the limbs?
An. Through the arteries.
Qu. Whence is it, that the Gout for the mot part manifets it elf in the extremities of the limbs of the body, as (for example) in the great Toe of the left Foot?
An. Becaue that the heart, undertaking the expulion, drives this offenive matter as far as it can.
Qu. May one from the Gout judg of the vigor and debility of the heart?
An. You may probably do o from the uffering part: For, if that be far from the heart, then the heart is trong; if near it, then 'tis les vigorous, and unable to end that noxious matter far away.
Qu. But when the heart through the arteries doth expel into the limbs, together with the nourihing blood, thee damps; mut thoe limbs receive them?

An. They mut receive them as well as the nutritive blood which accompanies it; the heart expelling them chiefly by the force of the arteries,
not reting till they be thrut out.
Qu. But why doth not the part aggrieved expel thoe damps, and end them further away?

An. Sometimes it doth o; namely, when the expelling force of uch a limb is trong and vigorous; for then it uffers not this bad guet to harbour there, but forces it by the veins to retreat back to the heart; whence it not eldom comes to pas, that by another expulion from the heart it falls upon a weaker limb; as we ee, that the pain which at firt was felt in the hand, oon after is found in the foot, &c.
Qu. When and how comes it to pas, that the limb is not able to drive or end away this peccant matter, but is contrained to lodge that unwelcome guet?
An. When the expelling vertue and the natural heat of that limb is defective, and too weak.

Qu. But, Sir, can you ully make it our, that thee malign damps take
their coure to the limbs, only through the arteries?

An. I can, my reaons being thee: Firt, I prove it by the beating pain, which, amongt others, is in the Gout one of the ure marks; for, that beating pain ufficiently hews, that the Gouty matter comes out of the arteries. Secondly, 'tis plain from the welling, ditenion, and quick pulation of the arteries, as thoe through which this matter takes its coure. Latly, 'tis mot evident from that remedy, which hath been ued by the ancient famous Phyitians, as likewie from our dicharging medicine.
Qu. What remedy of the Ancients do you mean?

An. That of Arteriotomy, or the opening of Arteries; by means whereof, they declare to have found incomparable more help and eae for the gouty Patient, than from the opening of veins; for a proof, that the gouty matter is protruded from the heart through the arteries.
Qu. But how doth it appear from your own Remedy?

An. Foramuch as the ame being applied to the Arteries, (when they by their trong pulation give ufficient aurance that the peccant matter is not yet quite expelled, but in part till harbours there,) fetches out that offenive tuff, and frees them therefrom; as we hall more plainly hew in our manner of curing the Tooth-ach: where it will manifetly appear, that this Burning of ours is not only a dicharging, but alo an excellent exhauting aid, forcing thee damps in the arteries and veins to evaporate.
Qu. Doth this painful matter caue no pain as long as it is included within the coats of the arteries?
An. It caues no pain until it does violence to the periotium, becaue the tunicles of the veins and arteries are void of feeling.
Qu. When the Arteries (in thoe that already feel great pain) do not ceae to beat trongly, what conclude you thence?
An. That the Gouty matter in part till rets in the arteries.
Qu. May this matter be totally expelled out of the arteries?
An. Not only it may; but the heart, as the ource of the arteries, never rets till it hath effected it.
Qu. Can this damp of it elf, or by too trongly repercutient means, be turned back again through the arteries to the heart?

An. Some indeed are of opinion that it can; but I ay that 'tis not poible: Nature, or rather the wie Author of it, having provided certain valves, which towards the heart are hut, and o hinder the return of blood and vapors thither through thoe veels.
Qu. Through what veels then returns this damp to the heart, as it often doth?
Qu. How comes it to pas that this damp returns to the heart?

An. Either when the expelling virtue, and the natural heat of the part that receives the damp is great; or when trong repelling means are unwarily applied; by which latter way the Patient is exceedingly prejudiced, becaue thereby the pernicious damp is made to return to the heart, which with o much labour had dicharged it elf from it; and there it caues Fevers, Anguih, and the like ditempers, and often Death it elf.

div.head: CHAP IX.
Of the Diagnoticks, or Signs of the Gout.
div.p: Qu. IS it neceary to know the proper Signs of the Gout?
An. Certainly it is; foramuch as thoe only are fit to cure the Gout, who know well the proper Signs thereof.
Qu. Hath there been no mitake herein hitherto?
An. There hath; for men have made thoe to be igns of the Gout that are none, as Inflammation, Heat, Fever, &c.
Qu. Which then, in your opinion, are the proper igns whereby the Gout can be bet ditinguihed from other ditempers?
An. Vitiated motion and Pain: which igns are preent from the beginning of the Gout, and as 'twere born with it, and do grow up with the ame to its height, and abate alo and vanih with it.
Qu. Are thee the only and always concomitant igns, by which we may know this inward, and, for the mot part, uneen windy tumor?
An. They are o; though wollen veins, and trong beating arteries, may alo be put for igns of the ame.
Qu. Thoe two firt, are they Signs only, or alo Symptoms?
An. They are ure igns, but they are alo ymptoms.
Qu. Inflammation, Heat, Fever, outward welling from afflux of humors, &c. why may not they be eteemed to be proper igns here?

An. Becaue they do not immediately follow the Dieae, nor any proper effects of the Gouty matter, nor do they always appear in the Gout; and therefore are deceitful igns, not to be truted to, and uch as have miled ome of the mot agacious men.
Qu. Are they to be reckoned amongt the Symptoms?
An. Not among the proper ymptoms of the Gout, but only uch as proceed from ome proper ymptom of the ame.
Qu. How is that pain conditioned, which you make to be a proper diagnotick or ign of the Gout, whereby the Gout, or the inward tumor in tho periotium, is made manifet?
An. 'Tis a pungent, ditending and beating pain, which begins and ends with the Gout, and grows up, and declines with the ame.
Qu. What denotes the pungent pain?
An. That the periotium uffers.
Qu. What the ditending pain?
An. That the enible membrane is raied and tretched by the Gouty matter.
Qu. What the beating pain?
An. That the gouty matter is already impacted and wedged in.
Qu. What ignifies the intolerable pain?
An. Both the plenty and malignity of the damps, whereby the enible periotium is forcibly evered from the bone, and tands by the force of the intruded winds bent, like a tring upon a bent Bow.

Qu. What doth the Pain indicate, which not only pervades all the parts of the body, upwards and downwards, but alo paes to the mot extreme part, in uch a degree, that the poor Patient can ret neither day nor night?

An. This plainly and palpably hews (beides what was jut now aid
in the next foregoing anwer,) that the membranes of the parts have a trict communication with one another, and a mutual ympathy.
Qu. What doth the Vitiated motion indicate, which increaes and decreaes as the Dieae doth?

An. Not that the organs of motion are attacked, hurt or tormented, but only that the periotium is put out of its natural poture; which is manifet from hence, that as oon as this membrane is retored to its natural tate, you cannot perceive the leat defect in thoe organs.
Qu. Why then doth the pain increae, and grow more violent upon touching or moving the part affected?

An. This comes not to pas becaue that the organs of motion, or their membranes do uffer; but becaue that the membrane being already ditended, by the touch or motion thereof it comes to uffer, and to tretch a new; whereupon new pain mut follow.

div.head: CHAP. X.
Of the Symptoms of the Gout.
div.p: Qu. FOramuch as there are found many and different Symptoms in the Gout, will it not be proper to make a ditinction between them, thereby to come to the true knowledg of them?
An. You will do very well to ditinguih firt the Symptoms in general from the Dieae it elf; and then to make a ditinction between the Symptoms themelves.
Qu. What ditinction is there to be made between the Symptoms of the Gout?
An. This; that the ymptoms that arie and vanih with the Dieae, are to be ditinguih'd from thoe that are bred not from the Gout, but from the ymptoms of the Gout.
Qu. Which are the Symptoms that do immediatly accompany the Gout, and are born and dye with it?
An. Of thee there are but two, already poken of, viz. the Vitiated motion, and the Violent pain: Thee come and go away with the Dieae, following the Gout as a hadow doth a body.
Qu. Which of thee two Symptoms is the chiefet and mot grievous?
An. The Pain; which is not the Dieae it elf, or the caue of the Gout, as hath been already aid; nor yet is it a imple Symptom, in regard it is a caue of other ymptoms, epecially when it is violent.
Qu. What Symptoms are occaioned, or rather caued thereby?
An. Inflammations, Fevers, Faintings, Sleepines, Los of trength, Afflux of humors.
Qu. Is it certain, that all thee ix Accidents are caued by the raging Pain of the Gout?

An. Dr. Paul Barbette reckons them all amongt the effects of the Gouty pain, when he treats of the Symptoms of Wounds in his Chirurgery,
p. 165. of his Dutch Edition. Beides that 'tis manifet, that mot of thee do then firt appear when the pain grows violent, and diappear with the diminution and ceaing of the pain.
Qu. Whence comes it, that thee Symptoms that are caued by the Gout, not only in divers Patients, but alo in the ame, hew themelves at one time more than another, and differ o much from one another?

An. It comes from the greater or leer intennes of the efficient caue, the Pain; which receives its degrees from the quality and quantity of the gouty matter. For the more malign and abounding the damps are, the more grievous alo are not only the proper Symptoms, but alo thee Accidents of the Gout.
Qu. Doth the raging pain excite in all Gouty perons thee Symptoms all together, and at once?

An. Not o; for in bodies that have but little eroity in the blood, the firt five Symptoms do appear;
but not at all, or very eldom, the ixth and lat, which is the afflux of humors: In others, who abound in that eroity, the afflux of moiture will be perceived firt of all, and often without inflammation. Again, when the gouty matter lurks deep, as in the Sciatica, and in the Gout of the houlders, you are not then to reckon upon the change of colour, and the afflux.
Qu. That raging pains do caue inflammations, is eaily undertood; but how do they produce Fevers, Faintings, Sleepines, and los of trength?
An. The intolerable pain drawing to the heart, caueth there a Fever and Fainting; and paing to the brain, produces there Waking: whence mut necearily follow Los of trength.

div.head: CHAP. XI.
Of the external Serous Tumor, which often manifests it elf in the Gout.
div.p: Qu. IS it worth while, to treat omewhat more largely of this Tumor, than of the other Symptoms caued by the Pain?

An. 'Tis very neceary, becaue by this Symptom many Learned men have been o miled, as to take it for the Gout-breeding matter it elf, or at leat not to ditinguih it from the Sicknes it elf: Whence, as from a fruitful oil, have prung o many errors about the Gout, and epecially about the proxime Caue thereof. Yea this is the only caue, that o many Phyitians and Chirurgians are o much wedded to the Notion of Humors, that they dare almot take it for granted, that the Gout cannot be without this Swelling and Afflux of Humors; inomuch, that if they meet with any Gouty
peron, in whom they cannot find this Swelling or change of Colour (although they find great pain,) they will rather dicard them out of the number of the Gouty, than acknowledg, that ometimes there are no humors at all accompanying the Gout.
Qu. But ince the Affluxed humor, which breeds the external welling, is neither in whole nor in part the Caue of the Gout, what hall we make of that tumor and its matter?

An. It is a Symptom, which is no ineparable companion of the Gout; yea never begins, and eldom ends with that dieae: Which I think I can o plainly make out, as that the mot ordinary capacity hall undertand it to be o.
Qu. Does then this erous Swelling not always accompany the Gout as an ineparable Symptom?

An. No; for, beides that ome Gouty perons eldom or never perceive this Tumor (caued by affluxed humors,) as I have experienced, and many Writers mut witnes; commonly
there is no affluxed Humor found in the Sciatica.
Qu. But does this Swelling never begin with the Gout?

An. 'Tis never perceived in the beginning of the Gout; for, though in many Patients this Tumor very oon follows upon the Gout; yet, if it be well oberved, it is never of the ame age with the Gouty tumor, which in order of time always precedes it: Yea, if care be had, its birth may ometimes be altogether prevented, by being timely ready to evaporate this dolorifick damp by a peedy application of my matchles dicharging Remedy; as I have often experimented on my elf, and hall further teach in the econd part, treating of the Cure of the Gout.
Qu. But as this Symptom never begins with the dieae, does it neither end always with it, as other Symptoms do?

An. No: This Symptom alone urvives the Gout; yea the caue whence it ries ends not with it. For,
as for the mot part it firt appears when the icknes is at its height, and the pain rageth; o it is often een a good while after the Gouty pain, and then by good means and ome patience dipelled.
Qu. It eems then, that the pain, which is the caue of this Symptom, ceaing, the outward tumor doth not vanih at the ame time?

An. No; for very often the limbs remain welled as before, and it requires ome days, and ome trouble, before this Swelling can be removed; yea, if you do not take care, it not only lames the Patient, but alo deforms him by Nodes and Schirres, whereby the Motion of the limbs is for ever detroyed.
Qu. What then is to be done, to judg aright of this Symptom?
An. You mut hold it for a certain truth, that the Humors which in the Gout breed the Swelling, are not the peccant or Gout-breeding matter.

Qu. To make me the better comprehend this, pray give me a clear decription
of this Swelling, which hath been the occaion of o many Errors, and hath deceived o many Learned men?
An. It is a Preternatural welling in the Flehy parts, coniting of a erous humor pervaded with altihnes, by the harp pain penetrated into the Limbs, and 'tis oft, pale, and cold.
Qu. But how may we bet ditinguih this Swelling from the Gout?
An. If it be view'd at the time when its Efficient caue is gone; for then it may be een in its true eence and qualities, and looks no otherwie than a Serous humor is wont to do.
Qu. I ee, you make two orts of Swellings in the Gout?
An. I do o; the one is Windy, which is the Gout it elf; the other Serous, which is a Symptom: And they differ exceedingly from one another.
Qu. Wherein conits that difference?

An. Chiefly in thee particulars: 1. In repect of the Name, which they
receive from their everal Caues; for the Gouty tumor coming from Winds, takes the name of Windy tumor; the other, coming from a erous humor, is called the Serous tumor. 2. In repect of the Part or Place affected; for, whereas the Windy tumor ditends the Membranes of the bones, the Serous fill the Carncous parts, as water a punge, and render the Fleh very pungy. 3. In regard of the Signs; for, whereas the Inward welling excites grievous and intolerable pain, the Serous none or little. 4. The Internal welling is a proper dieae; the other is raied by the pain, and is a Symptom bred by Conent of parts.
Qu. But ince that the Serous tumor in the Gout is not produced by any External caue, but by an Internal, what is this Caue?

An. The violent pain, as hath been often aid, which is here the caue of the Afflux of humors, it being known by Artits, that Pain draws humors after it; which therefore is by them aigned to be one of the principal
caues of the Afflux of humors.
Qu. But are thee humors, of which this kind of Swelling conits, drawn into the uffering parts by the Pain alone?

An. Artits are wont to add, that ympathizing Nature, as a kind Mother, uccours the uffering part by ending moiture to it; and accordingly this Swelling hould be generated by Sympathy of Conent of the parts.
Qu. What benefit or eae doth the part affected receive from ympathiing nature by her ending thoe humors thither?
An. That the raging pain is thereby mitigated, and rendred more tolerable.
Qu. In what manner is that done, or how doth the conveyed humor awage the enraged pain?

An. Though this be difficult to explain; yet I cannot agree to the common opinion, importing, that the Pain-breeding matter by means of the conveyed humors is driven outward,
and dipered thorough the neighbouring fleh, and o the uffering member for a great part freed of the pain-cauing matter: For, the conveyed humors can by no means approach or come to the dolorifick matter, much les fotch it out of its deep eat, and dilodge it, becaue 'tis o fat impacted and included under o firm and cloe a Bone-membrane.
Qu. What is then, in your opinion, the reaon why the harp pain is often diminihed upon the afflux of moiture, not only in the Gout, but alo in the Tooth-ach? &c.

An. Methinks 'tis probable, that 'tis done after this manner: The muculous flehy parts being by the conveyed humors rendred ofter, plumper, and more pongious, and conequently gentler, do not, in the firt place, pres againt, or rather reit o much the enible and ditended periostium, as before, when the carneous parts had but their own native and proper moiture. Secondly, the periostium being by the conveyed moiture from
without made gentler, may with les pain be tretch'd; and it may alo come to pas, that by that little warmth, which this erous matter hath in it at firt, it being now come near the periostium doth omewhat attenuate the included gros damp, and o the better dipoe it to evaporate.
Qu. But doth the affluxed humor occaion no michief?
An. Very much, and ometimes more than the Gout it elf; for without care it caueth Dilocation of the uffering members, and the Nodes.

div.head: CHAP. XII.
Of the Dilocation.
div.p: Qu. HOw is it poible, that the Gout-breeding matter hould caue a Dilocation?
An. By the plentious tock of humors conveyed and drawn in.

Qu. But how; doth this abundant moiture, falling into the cavity of the
joynts, forcibly thrut the bones out of their cavity?

An. Not o; but 'tis done in manner following: Pain and Nature cooperating, the one by drawing in, the other by conveying, bring uch a quantity of humors to the uffering part (for example, the Hipp,) that thereby, in time, the trong ligaments, which tye the bones together, are o ouzed thorow, that being debilitated they tretch and grow o lax, that the bone falls out of its cavity, and o caueth dilocation: Of which we have many ad Examples.
Qu. Doth not this michief fall often out in other Caes?

An. It may happen in all the members of the body; and then epecially, when an unskilful or imprudent Mater by the ue of wrong means occaioneth yet a greater afflux of humors than hath been already drawn in by the pain, and furnih'd by nature: Of which, Pareus records a memorable Example in the Dilocation of the knees, caued by a Pariian
Mater, called Greaulm, fol. 256.
Qu. May this Dilocation be prevented by Art?
An. Very well; as hall be hewn in that part of our Book, which is to treat of the Cure of the Gout, and its Symptoms.

div.head: CHAP. XIII.
Of the Nodes.
div.p: Qu. IS there yet more danger to be apprehended from this Symptom, or its matter?
An. There is; for if you take not great care, it will change into an incurable Scirrbus or hard tumor, which in the Gout are called Nodes, according to that of Ovid;
Qu. When comes this welling to change to uch an hardnes?

An. To borrow the words of Beverovicius; when the thin humor is inenibly exhaled, and the ediment rets behind, then will that turn into hard knobs, which burting of themelves, or being opened, render a chalky or uch like matter, whereby our limbs are not only deprived of motion, but alo dipoed to crookednes.
Qu. How many ways are thee tony wellings generated?
An. Two; either of themelves, or by the unskilfulnes of the pretended Artit.
Qu. When of themelves?

An. The Evaporation of the ubtiler or thinner parts of thee humors may be caued by the natural and innate warmth of the uffering part, aited by the adjacent parts, as alo by the preternatural heat of the inflammation of the ame, without any other external caue: Whereupon the gros, thick, altih, and carthy parts,
as the ediment and relicks remaining in the limb, are coagulated and concreted.
Qu. I. undertand you very well; but, I pray, tell me alo, how may this come to pas by the Unskilfulnes of Practitioners?

An. When they apply too trongly repelling, or drying, or too much cooling remedies, which drive the thinner parts inward, or dipel them, and o harden and render incurable the thicker tuff; whereas they hould ue moderately warm mollifying remedies, thereby to expel and conume the whole matter.
Qu. Do thee Nodes, when they are caued without the application of pervere remedies, grow on leiurely?

An. They do o, when they are bred of themelves: For, the foundation of this chalky matter being once laid, 'tis raied and encreaed more and more upon every new afflux, and from time to time caled over, until it comes to that bignes,
that it only hinders the motion of the limb, and renders it crooked, but can alo tay or have room no longer under the skin, but making it firt protuberant, burts it at length in pieces.
Qu. Surely an ignorant Practitioner can bring this to pas much ooner?

An. So he can, and to uch a degree, that the poor Patient in the very firt fit of the Gout is for ever deprived of the motion of the uffering limb; of which we have in Banda an Example of a Lieutenant of ours, now lying here in Garrion, called Jan van Haerlem.
Qu. But may not this growing of Tophes or Nodes be prevented and hindred?
An. Very well; as hall be taught in the Cure of the Symptoms of the Gout.
Qu. Will you proceed now to the econd principal you intended, viz, the Cure of the Gout?

An. I will, after you have heard
what I had to ay of the Nature and Caue of the Gout, its Seat and Part affected, its Diagnoticks, Symptoms, and the neceity of ditinguihing thee latter not only from the dieae it elf, but alo from one another: All which have made way to judg the better of a fit Remedy to cure the ame; eeing we cannot hope for Cure, before the Malady be throughly undertood.

div.head: THE SECOND PART: Of the CURE of the GOUT.
CHAP. I.
Treating of the Cure of the Gout, in general.
div.p: Qu. HAve there not been at all times men that have pretended to the skill of Curing the Gout?

An. Yes indeed; but Experience hath put them to hame: For whereas they have promied cheap and ure remedies againt this painful dieae, their promie hath notoriouly failed, and their Patients have been
at lat abandoned remediles. See hereof, amongt others, Fabritius Hildanus his econd Part, p. 174. where he peaks of one, whom he calls a Monter, that highly bragged, he could conquer that great Enemy of Mankind, the Arthritis or Gout, but was confuted by very ad Experience.
Qu. Why doth he call him a Monter?
An. Becaue of that montrous and michievous means by him ued, whereby he killed his Gouty Patients. See in the ame Hildanus his econd part, p. 87, that unhappy preparation of Quickilver for the Gout.
Qu. But have none of the bet Phyitians of Europe in o many Ages found any ure Remedy againt this Dieae?

An None that I know of; they rather call the Gout Ludibrium Medicorum, and the Dieae of Richmen; though it eizes alo on the Poor, who, if they could be helped, would oon loe that name. Hence
'tis become a Proverbial aying, viz. that he who undertakes to perform omething extraordinary, is like him that pretends to Cure the Gout: Which pretenders are uually ent to the Courts of Kings and Princes, to practie their skill on them, who will not ail to make uch men rich, as hall perform uch undertakings.
Qu. What's the matter then, that the true Remedy hath not been found hitherto? is the fault in the Phyitians, or in the Gouty Patients?
An. In both, but mot in the former, as not knowing the true nature of this Dieae, notwithtanding all their Diputes and Dicoures about it.

Qu. What do you think of Cardanus his aying in the praie of the Gout, viz. That whooever will top the ource of the Gout, tops withall the ource of life: Doth not this imply, that the Gout is incurable?

An. He will ay, that the Root of the Gout cannot be totally pulled out, though you may trip off the
Leaves, that is, remove the outward Accidents thereof.

div.head: CHAP. II.
That the Gout is curable by Burning with Moxa.
div.p: Q. BUT pray, let me know your opinion in this matter: Is the Gout an incurable Evil, and Cardanus his aying true?
A. I or the comfort of all the Gouty, I here openly and joyfully declare, that 'tis Curable:
Q. But is not this a preumptuous Arrogance?

A. No; for the good God, in compaion to mankind, hath been pleaed not only to bring me to the true knowledg of the nature and condition of this Dieae, but alo to direct me to a pecifick and proper remedy thereof, which removes this ore Evil, it being now, through the divine goodnes, in our power to quell and tame
this Gyant, without making our elves guilty of any vanity.
Q. What means is this, I pray?

A. 'Tis the harmles Burning with Moxa, which being three or four or more times repeated, according to the condition of the place which the Gout hath eized on, pulls the Enemy out of his fatnees. Mark it, the raging Gout in the height of its rage, is firt topp'd in its carrier, and oon after forced to pack away.
Q. Is this poible?
A. It is; for I have uccesfully experienced it on my elf, and many others.

div.head: CHAP. III.
How, and for what this Remedy is ued.
div.p: Q. BUT to peak with order of the Cure of the Gout, what is above all to be conidered in this Dieae?

A. The uffering part and labouring nature is to be uccour'd without delay, and the part affected to be delivered of the incloed damp; the Cure principally coniting herein, viz. in giving an out-let to the Gout-breeding or peccant matter, and even in forcing it to evaporate.
Q. Which then is the remedy, that performs o great an effect? Is it not known in Europe? Where hath it been found out?

A. 'Tis Moxa, bet known amongt thoe of China and Japan: o celebrated, valued, and commended there, that no other remedies are to be compared therewith upon the account of its excellent performances; conidering that there are few pains in the body, for which they do not ue it with great benefit.

div.head: CHAP. IV.
What Moxa is, and where to be had.
div.p: Q. BUT what is this Moxa?
An. 'Tis a very oft and woolly ubtance, made by a very skilful preparation out of a certain dried Herb.
Q. What name hath that Herb, out of which this woolly matter is prepared? Is it not known amongt us?
A. The name is unknown to me; but I am well aured, that 'tis one of the bet Herbs under the Sun, and may very jutly bear the name of Mater Herbarum.
Q. Is there requiite a particular skill to prepare it?
A. Yes verily; and there is none of all the Droguits of Europe that have that skill.
Q. Is the preparation of it much valued by the Chinees and Japanees?
A. This Art is by thoe Nations o highly valued, that they will not for any mony communicate it to other Nations, but do keep it for a great ecret.
Q. Do they in China and Japan publickly vend it?
A. They drive a good trade with it, and carry it in whole bales through thoe vat Empires for ale.
Q. Which of thoe Nations hath the reputation to prepare it bet?
A. The Chinees do herein ar excel the Japonees; as they alo do in preparing and conerving all other orts of Medicines.
Q. Is this prepared Herb in great eteem with thoe people?
A. In o great an one, that they are eldom found to be without it.
Q. For what ue do they employ this woolly ubtance?
A. For an actual Cautick, and an efficacious dicharging remedy.
Q. Againt what Dieaes, and in what places of the Body?
A. Againt all indipoitions ariing from cold Damps and Humors, and in all places of the Body, none (that I know) but the eyes excepted.
Q. Do they find good from this Cautick.
A. Exceeding great, and that with great afety; by vertue thereof freeing the Body from all lurking winds and cold humors.

div.head: CHAP. V.
Directing how this Remedy is to be ued.
div.p: Q. IN what manner do they ue this matter for a Cautick, and in what quantity?

A. They make between their fingers a little pellet of this woolly ubtance, which is carce of the bignes of a mall white pea, at one end omewhat harp, and at the other end flat; and this they put with the flat end on the place where the Burning is to be
made, etting fire to the upper harp end by ome mall Aromatick ticks, exprely prepared for it, which yield a very grateful cent.
Q. Doth this woolly matter catch fire quickly?
A. When 'tis competently dry, it catches fire ooner than any tinder: whence the Chinees employ it alo in their Tinder-boxes.
Q. Doth this pellet, when kindled, turn all to ahes?
A. Never wholly, but there always remains a little bottom that is not incinerated.
Q. What may be the caue that 'tis not wholly turn'd to ahes?

A. The moiture which by this burning matter is drawn out of the uffering place; of which moiture indeed the greatet part flies away in fume, but yet ome of it draws into the burning pellet, and o moitens it that it cannot all be converted into ahes.
Q. Can the humors under the skin be een with the naked eye to run towards the burning pellet?
A. Very well, it being done with more peed than men are wont to run to an houe that is on fire.
Q. Doth this Burning raie no bliters in the skin?
A. None at all; it only caues a little grey peck, though the pellet be divers times ucceively kindled upon the ame place.
Q. What reaon is there for it, that the fire here raieth no bliters?
A. None other, but that the pellet burns not quite thorough to the skin.
Q. Doth not this Burning caue intolerable pain?
A. The pain is very tolerable, becaue the matter is woolly and oft, not cloe nor thick; and the pellet is mall, and burns not unto the very skin.
Q. How long lats the Burning of one pellet?
A. About the time of telling fifty.
Q. How often is the Burning repeated upon one place?

A. Ordinarily thrice upon weak
and tender limbs; but upon other places, if need be, o often till the pain be removed, although you hould (for example in the Sciatica) on one and the ame place kindle 25, yea 50 pellets; of which you need not fear the leat inconvenience, but may expect the better dicharge.
Q. But doth not this Burning occaion great after-pain?
A. None at all; but as the fire is out, you may handle the place burnt without cauing any pain; and, which is more, you may cruh and pres it as hard as you pleae.
Q. Doth this Burning take away the pain that is in the place or part, or only mitigate it?
A. It doth both, to admiration.

div.head: CHAP. VI.
What is to be done after the Burning upon the places where it hath been made?
div.p: Q. SO then, there is nothing to be done after the Burning upon the part burnt to eae the after-pain?

A. I told you jut now, there is no uch thing as after pain: But yet you mut not leave weak nature to her elf alone, but you ought to aid her, and to ue means to eparate the little Ecar as oon as is poible.
Q. What is to be done herein?

A. Lay a little beaten Leek upon the aid Ecar, and over that, one of the outermot coats of the ame Leek, a little moitned in the mouth; the which, like a plaiter, keeps the beaten Leek fat upon the Ecar. This being taken off together, ome 24 hours after, more or les, you'l ee the little Ecar dipoed to eparation, appearing to have round about it a circle
of clear skin, which ometimes alo ries to a wound or bliter, which may with ciers be opened to give it vent.

Q. Is not this little Ecar to be treated with inciion, and to be taken away with little pincers or lancets, that o the ill which may lurk there may evaporate? Or is it better to leave it for nature further to open the Ecar, and to throw it off?

A. Beware to ue any evere means (from ill-grounded coniderations) or any force; for great pain may thereby be occaioned: And therefore ue only warm Plantin-leaves to make the Ecars fall off, patiently taying till they fall off by that means, and the part heal up; the which is effected by provident Nature her elf, if it be good for the part affected.
Q. But when the Ecar eems to be already looe, and even to hang doubled in the little wound, is it not then to be taken away?
A. No.

Q. If the Ecar is ever'd, and
taken away by Nature her elf, and the pus or matter looks like lard, is not this ro be removed one way or another?
A. You are not o much as to touch it, bur leave it to Nature to dipoe thereof,
Q. Mut you not do your bet with the greatet peed to heal up the burnt places?
A. No; but rather you are to keep them open as long as you can, yet without changing them into Iues by putting peas or pellets into them.
Q. How is that to be done?

A. By laying upon them warm Plantin-leaves, with the rough ide to the skin. I ay, they mut be laid on warm, not cold: And this is to be done not by holding the leaves in warm water, but by laying them on glowing wood-coals; where they mut lie until you ee them begin to fall-in; and then they are to be taken off and rolled tiff together betwixt the palms of the hands, and then to
be unrolled and diplaid again, being yet warm and moit, and o laid on the Ecar: Continuing this until it be time to heal up the wound; when the leaf, being prepar'd again after the former manner, is to be laid on with the mooth ide to the skin; by which means it will heal up without leaving a mark upon the part, and much better than if you had employed the bet plaiters.
Q. Why mut thee Leaf-plaiters lie a great while upon the part with the rough ide, and at lat only with the mooth ide?
A. Becaue the rough ide draws out, and the mooth ide heals?

Q. Is there n
thing ele to be oberved touching thee vegetable plaiters?
A. They are to be kept from falling off by ome compres of linnen rags; and to be refrehed or renewed twice in 24 hours.

Q. But in cae the burnt places could not well endure the ue of linnen compres, how then may thee
Leaf-plaiters be ecured from falling off?
A. You may lay over them a Diapalma or Bailicum-plaiter, only to keep the Leaf upon the Ecar.
Q. But if Plantin-leaves be not to be had, may not other leaves erve?

A. In that cae you may ue red Cabbage or Colts-foot-leaves; and, if thee cannot be had, employ the aid Diapalma or Bailicum-plaiters: Which may chiefly tand you in good tead, when you are travelling by water or land.

div.head: CHAP. VII.
Of the admirable Effects of this Cautick.
div.p: Q. MAY a man ret in this application, and expect the deired cure?

A. You may, by God's bleing; and the Phyitian may look for honour, conidering that in o doing he
cureth urely, without inconvenience, and even with pleaure.
Q. Then, it eems, there is no danger in the right ue of this remedy?
A. None at all; yea it is uch an one, than which there will hardly be devied a better, and of which you will really ee a wonderful effect for the good of the Patient.
Q. Will it uccour nature with mot peed, and free her of the evil that encumbers and torments her?

A. It will; whereas Hippocrates l. 6. Aph. 49. aith, that the Gout requires 40 days to cure it; which Galen econds, with the adding this condition, viz. if the Phyitian undertand his work, and the Patient do his part in oberving carefully what is precribed. But this our Moxa, by means of the Burning decribed, draws this Wolf with peed out of his den, and delivers the Patient intantly from his pains and anguih.
Q. But is this way of curing ure?

A. So ure that it fails not, but is
always beneficial; and the ucces of it is o manifet, that it cannot be doubted.
Q. But you did add, that it would cure with pleaure; which I undertand not, ince you have above acknowledged, that this Burning is not without ome pain.

A. I mean thus, that the Cure is pleaant, in regard that upon a little harp pain, which lats but a hort time, there follows a great pleaure and joy; the fruits of this hort pain being great and every way delightful, foramuch as the poor Patient, dicharged from the intolerable pain of the Gout, intead of his doleful lamentations and outcries hath now caue to rejoyce, and to break out into thanks.
Q. But is this all, which the Burning with Moxa produceth?
A. No; for the ame, being timely ued, hinders the afflux of humors, though not always totally, yet at leat in great part.
Q. What benefit arieth from thence?

A. Thereby is prevented all the michief, which otherwie may be occaioned by the afflux of humors; uch as is Dilocation and Nodes: Whereas 'tis certain, that thoe who ue this way of Burning duly and maturely, hall never have caue to complain of thoe grievous effects.
Q. If all this be true, this remedy may be extrolled to the sky?

A. Not only that; but it enables the Patient to be upon his legs, and to follow his vocation, if it be not too toilome; and even to travel without any coniderable trouble: By the ame alo he is exempt from all other tedious and cotly tuff, alves, ointments, plaiters, &c.

div.head: CHAP. VIII.
Shewing, that this Burning with Moxa goes beyond all other Remedies of Europe hitherto ued againt the Gout.
div.p: Q. BUT when the Phyitians of Europe and other parts from hence have better undertood the nature of the Gout, will they not be able to find out a better Remedy againt it?

A. 'Tis probable, that upon the acquiition of the true knowledg of this dieae, they will not deviate o far as before from the way of curing it, and that in all probability they will echew many errors and mitakes; but they will never find out any better remedy than this Burning with Moxa, it being the bet, becaue the peediet, cleanliet and afet, yea the mot genuine, mot ecure, and mot accommodate means, that can be excogitated by men.
Q. May not the encloed wind, which you ay caueth all the trouble, be drawn out by Sudorificks, Cupping-glaes, Iues, Leeches, or common Cauticks?

A. By Sudorificks poibly there might be effected the greatet eae, but the evil would not be fully removed, eeing that thereby only the ubtilet of the gourty damps would be exhaled. And for Cupping-glaes, Iues, Leeches, and Cauticks, none of them is able to fetch out this evil from its deep-lurking hole, which is under the cloe and firm membrane which invets the bones.
Q. Is it not adviable to employ Anodines?
A. By no means, becaue the pain is thereby not removed, but only palliated and dulled; but is afterwards raied up into greater rage.
Q. Is not Letting of Blood beneficial, as many would maintain?

A. Letting of blood is better omitted, for thee reaons: Firt, becaue, according to the opinion of the bet,
'tis not adviable, when the pain is raging, to open a vein. Secondly, 'tis not the Blood that's peccant or faulty, but the ill-conditioned Damps, which indeed run together with the blood and pirits in the veels, but do never o mix with the blood, as to make one body, but may eaily be ever'd: Whereas 'tis otherwie with the Blood and Spirits, they two making up one body; as the heat and water contitute hot water, or as wine and the pirits thereof make one body of wine. Thirdly, by Blood-letting the noxious Damps are drawn inwards to the Heart, and there occaion much michief, and the benefit you look for from it will not countervail the harm. Fourthly, the forces of the Patient are thereby diminihed, and Nature is enervated in her conlict with the dieae; whereas a good Artit ought always to befriend Nature by trengthning her againt her enemy; and a wie Phyitian will not be forward to hed blood, but preerve it as the treaure of life: And as a Seaman
in a tempet will not throw his Bread over board, but rather uch commodities as he can be without; o a good Phyitian will keep the blood of his Patient, and drive out ill Damps.
Q. What do you think of alves, oils, or other unctuous medicaments in this cae?
A. They cloe the pores, and obtruct evaporation.
Q. What opinion have you of hot Pickle, humane rine, warm Cowdung, &c.
A. They are means which are apt to mitigate, yea ometimes to remove the pain; but not always, or very lowly, nor radically.

Q. Would not an Hot iron be convenient to make this damp exhale, as was practied in the Sciatica upon Jacobus Vincus, Ambaador of the Prince of Lansbergen; witnes Dr. Nicolaus Tulpius, Burgemater of Amterdam, in his Obervations, ch. 26. p. 228; by which means that Gentleman was freed from his trouble?

A. 'Tis too ierce, and withal too dangerous a remedy; practicable indeed, (notwithtanding the contrary judgment of Fabrit. Hildanus in his 6th part, p. 501;) but 'tis better to ue our gentle way of Burning, which, by far, caues no uch pain, and is more beneficial without putting nature o hard to it. To confirm this, I hall now only add, what Herls aith in his Examen of Chirurgery, p. 364. viz. The burning with a red-hot Iron is too violent a way for Chirurgions, and too painful for Patients, and can eldom be ued without hurting the fleh and mucles. And doubtles all Phyitians and Chirurgions will be of the ame mind, as oon as this way of Burning with Moxa hall come to their knowledg; my opinion being, that they will never make ue more of an hot Iron but in uch caes, wherein the aid Burning is not powerful enough, as, for example, in the Rottennes of bones, and the like.

Q. What think you of Spanih
Flies, now of o frequent ue; of which Jobus van Mekeren writes in his Obervations, that he hath ued them with much benefit againt the Gout, following the advie of Dr. Vopius Fortunatus P. lempius?

A. I eteem, that all intelligent Phyitians and Chirurgions will much rather make ue of our Moxa for the good of their Patients, they knowing ufficiently the venemounes of thoe Spanih Flies, and how hurtful they are to the Bladder and other vicera; and having ued them long enough of neceity, becaue they knew no better means. And 'tis remarkable what Aquapendente warns of the qualities of Spanih Flies in his Art of Chirurgery, ch. 3. p. 246. concluding with thee words, That 'tis madnes to ue this deadly remedy.
Q. Is the Burning with Moxa les painful than that with an Iron?

A. Incomparably les; nor is it o Dangerous, according to the golden rule of Hippocrates, lib. 2. Aph. 12. That to heat much, and uddenly, is
dangerous; but to do it by little and little, and lowly, is without danger. And this is it, what the expert Phyitian Guilandin confeeth in Proper Alpinus de Medic. Aegyptiorum, ch. 12. in that remarkable practice of the Burning in Cairo, and thereabout: Which Chapter highly deerves to be conidered.
Q. But, Sir, do you not apprehend, that the Aegyptian manner of Burning will go beyond that with your Moxa?

A. Not at all, being well aured, that the Aegyptians will be very glad to exchange their Cotton and Stramineous linnen with our Moxa, as oon as they hall know the admirable vertue and effect thereof. Nor is the Burning with Moxa by far o painful, as all the world will judg, when they hall ee and compare both.
Q. Then, I pray, Sir, be pleaed to repeat in hort, what remedy it mut be, that hall free a man from this dieae?

A. The genuine Cure of this Evil, which attacks uddenly, and will not
bear delay without great injury to the Patient, conits in the removal of the Caue, and requires a remedy, having thee following proprieties. Firt, it mut powerfully open not only the Pores of the Skin, but thoe alo of the Membranes of Bones. Secondly, it mut attenuate the cold thick damps, and reit their malignity.
