Thirdly, it mut trengthen the innate heat, and the expulive force of the part affected, thereby the better to mater and remove the Evil. Now the Burning with Moxa performs all this: It trongly draws out from the deep, and reits all malignity; it attenuates the cold and crae vapors lurking under the membranes, conuming or extracting them, and o disburthening nature of her enemy; latly, it o corroborates the weak uffering par
that it will not o eaily receive and lodge again Damps of that nature.

div.head: CHAP. IX.
Shewing, that this Burning is very tolerable.
div.p: Qu. BUT do you think, you can eaily induce your Patients to undergo this Burning?
A. Certainly being well intructed they will quickly ubmit to it; though that kind of Burning which hitherto hath been ued in Europe, hath made men very avere from that way.
Q. How may they be bet perwaded to it?

A. I would rather have them perwaded by other prudent and undertanding perons, than by the Phyitian himelf. For as to him, it will be more adviable, he hould eem himelf cool in this buines, and tay to be intreated.
Q. But in cae they will not be induced to it out of that pervere apprehenion, what then?

A. If they be o delicate as not to ubmit to o light a pain, they deerve not to be cured, and o mut keep their Dieae: But, I preume it will be with you as 'twas at firt with me, who having from an idle fear refued this Burning, was afterward contrained by the grievous and raging pain to deire the ue thereof. And ince that Gouty perons mut day and night combat againt the intolerable pain of the Gout, certainly they will not eaily be afraid of this innocent way of Burning. I have een weak and timorous women, and young maids, which made nothing of it, in repect of the pain they had indured in their teeth and head: Not now to peak of Children, who without much cry and tears have endured this Burning, to be cured of that kind of Dropie called the Tympanites, and of other infirmities, and particularly of Convulions.

Q. But many Doctors and Chirurgions are like to condemn this remedy as new and unknown, and o render
it upected among their Patients?
A. The Effect will oon ilence you, and convince you of envy and ignorance.
Q. But may not this Dieae be cured by gentler remedies?
A. No: You may indeed mitigate the pain by gentler means, but not remove the caue, nor root the Evil out of the part affected; which may bet be done by this our Burning.

div.head: CHAP. X.
Of the Qualification required in the peron that is to perform this Burning.
div.p: Q. IS every one fit to perform this Burning?
A. No certainly; but it mut be one that hath a perfect knowledg of what is requiite to it, both before and after, and that is experienced in it; becaue coniderable mitakes may be committed therein.
Q. What are the particulars, of which this Artit mut be well intructed?

A. Firt, of the Dieae, to the cure of which this Burning is to be ued. Secondly, of the Remedy or Moxa, and its vertue, as alo of the Herb, and the way of preparing it. Thirdly, he mut know in what manner this Burning is to be made, and what is to be done both before, in, and after the ame.
Q. What ele is required thereto?

A. The Practitioner mut be a peron of a good ight, not unwieldy of body, having leady and dry, no trembling nor weaty hands; for ele he will not be able to give to the pellets their due form or hape, to put them fat upon the right place, and to make them catch fire: All which is to be done with a particular dexterity and expedition, that o the patient may not be held any time in fear.
Q. Pray, will you teach me, how the good Moxa is to be ditinguih't from that which is naught?
A. By your ight, mell, and touch.
Q. How by the ight?
A. That which is good hath a fine gray colour?
Q. How by the mell?
A. It hath a grateful eent?
Q. How by the touch?

A. It mut be oft like fine wool; if it be hard or tubborn, 'tis then unfit for this Burning. And if it have this lat quality relating to the touch, though the colour and cent were omewhat decayed, it would not be unfit for this purpoe.

div.head: CHAP. XI.
Of the little Aromatick ticks, and their e.
div.p: Q. BUT where is this Moxa to be had?

A. It mut by the Commiioners of the East-India Company be ent for out of China: Which will be very
well worth the while, ince it will prove a gainful commodity in Europe, and be no bruthen to hips.
Q. What ue is there of thoe Aromatick ticks you have mentioned?

A. They are neceary to kindle the Moxa with; and thee mut likewie be had every year out of China or Japan: They alo by their pleaing cent when kindled, keep the Patient and Bytanders, and the Operator, from the ungrateful and offenive mell, which the gouty damps emit when by the burning Moxa they are forced to evaporate; epecially if it be conidered, what ill the mell of uch tinking vapors may caue in our Bodies.
Q. Are thee ticks prepared by Art?
A. They are o, and that of everal orts of well-cented wood, of which Santal is the chiefet. And they mut be very tenderly handled, being very ragile.
Q. I or what ue do the Chinees and Japonees employ thee ticks?
A. For burning; but mot for perfuming before their Idols.
Q. May they be kept good for a long time?
A. For ome years, if they be kept hut up in a dry box.
Q. May they not be had at Batavia from China, together with the Moxa?
A. They may; but in cae a great quantity were required to erve all Europe, it mut be ent for from China or Japan.

div.head: CHAP. XII.
Of the Place where the Burning is to be made.
div.p: Q. IN what place is this Burning to be made?

A. In all places where the Gout-breeding matter is eated, and caueth great pain. And here the rule of Hippocrates may be applied: Burn where pain is. Wherefore the Phyitian
or Chirurgian mut needs exactly know the very eat of the gouty pain, without which the operation is for the mot part fruitles. And if the application be made but an inch wide from the very part that is in pain, it would not have the deired effect.
Q. Since it is of that importance to know well the true eat of the pain how may it bet be found?
A. By the Eye and Touch.
Q. How by the Eye?

A. The Mater ought to have Eagles eyes, and then by looking attentively he will oon py the place epecially if the pain be very great and violent, and the gouty limb by the affluxed humor not much welled: For then the Inflammation directs manifetly to the very eat of the pain and hews the hole of this raging wolf. And in this cae one may eaily ee the genuine Gout-or Wind-tumor by taking notice of a little ditenion and tanding out of the skin, appearing like a mall putule; on the extant
head of which, if the burning be applied, the Patient will be freed of all pain, o as that the Bytanders will admire, and all Gainayers be convinced of the vertue and power of this remedy.
Q. But in cae the Seat of the Gout hould not be viible, how is it then to be found out?

A. Conidering that this motly happens in perons that are the firt time attacked by the Gout, and often alo in thoe that are ubject to a great afflux of humors from the Gout; it will be incumbent on the Mater to be very coutious in finding out the true eat of the pain, that o he may not put the Patient to unneceary torment. And therefore he mut with his fore-finger feel o long upon or about the place, where the Patient complains of mot pain, until by the Patients greatet ene he do find out the true place; which, to avoid all mitake, he mut touch again and again, and then perform the operation of Burning accordingly.

Q. Pray, Sir, inform me, Whether the people in China and Japan ar
ubject to the Gout?
A. This evil raigns as well in thoe parts of the World, as in Europe, and even among the Hottentots on the Cape of Good Hope.
Q. Do thee Nations cure themelves and others of the Gout, urely and peedily?
A. No, they do not, except it be caually: which may be wondred at.

Q. What's the matter, eeing they have poeed this excellent means
Burning from immemorial times?

A. 'Tis not the want of a good remedy, but their tubbornes, upertition and pervere cutome, th
they do not cure the Gout but by chance or good fortune. For they have been taught indeed to burn in very many, but yet in certain determined and precribed places of the body; not being to be induced to trangres thoe precriptions, though the pain hould require it. If then
it chanceth, that the Gout its jut in the place, where they are accutomed to burn, it is cured; but if it happen to be eated one inch more or les from the place prefixed, and call for the operation of Burning, they let the Patient complain and cry out, and will not uccour Nature where he needs it. And this is the true caue, why they enjoy not that benefit againt the Gout by this way of Burning, as they might do.
Q. Is it then allow'd and adviable to burn upon all places where the gouty pain is eated, though there be Veins, Arteries and Nerves underneath?

A. Yes, without exception; foramuch as this kind of Burning, being perform'd after my precription, cannot hurt thee parts or veels; yea 'tis beneficial, by this burning to dicharge the wollen veins and arteries of their damps: And therefore the precribed pellets may and mut be burnt out jut upon them; as hall be more particularly directed hereafter in the Tooth-ach.
Q. But now, the place being found out, is there nothing that may hinder the Burning?

A If there be any hair upon the place affected, that mut be haved off with a raor; in regard that the leat hair impedes the Burning, becaue it keeps the
ine pellet from perfectly touching the skin.
Q. Is there nothing ele in the way?

A. If the place, where the Burning is to be made, be fatty or moit, that atnes and moitnes mut be taken away, and the place duly cleaned and dried: That done, put the little pellet upon the right place, and there burn it, repeating it o often till the gouty pain be gone.
Q. But how may it bet be known, what effect this Burning hath produced?

A. The Patient will oon find that by the diminution of the pain and of the inflammation, and the Mater, that adminiters, mut, (if the Burning have been made upon an ordinary
place of any tender limb, to three, four or five times ucceively,) pres with his fore-finger hard upon the Ecar, to learn whether the dolorifick gouty matter be wholly drawn out or not, which the Patient is with freedom to declare, if he means to be fully cured, and not in part: For, if he deceives the Mater, he mot deceives and wrongs himelf.
Q. If the pain with three pellets be quite removed, as commonly it is, will it be neceary to trouble him with any more?
A. By no means.
Q. But in cae the Patient, contrary to expectation, hould out of tendernes and effeminacy, in the burning of the firt pellet, which caueth mot pain, cry out and grow impatient, what then?

A. The Mater in that cae is not to mock or laugh at him, but only hew a chearful countenance, and entertain the Patient with a dicoure of the excellency of the remedy, of the hortnes of the time that the operation
will lat, and of the number of perons that have been cured thereby.

Q. But pray tell me, Sir, what's the reaon, that this Burning hath been o many years hid from us Europeans, whereas it hath been experienced for o vat a time in thoe Indian Kingdoms, where it is o common, and is ued for the mot part with great benefit?

A. This is to be imputed to the carelenes and conceitednes of the Europeans, becaue having o good an opinion of themelves, they are ahamed to learn any good thing from thoe Pagans; as if they alone were poeed of all knowledg, and thoe Nations had no hare at all in it: Without which conceit and negligence, this excellent remedy might have been long before communicated to thee parts of the World.

div.head: CHAP. XIII.
Treating of the michiefs, inconveniences, and dangers of the Burning miued.
div.p: Q. BUT, may any ill be occaioned by this Burning?

A. There may; and even in Japan, China, and other places, coniderable mitakes are committed in the Ue of this Burning, whereby ome, uing it without fear or wit, do caue not only grievous and fitulous wounds, but alo lamenes of limbs.
Q. Pray, explain to us more particularly, how thee evils proceed from this Burning miued?

A. To be hort, when, after the manner of ome Japonees, the Burning is made too much and too deep, without due regard had to the places to which the Burning is to be applied: Whence it comes to pas, that Nature being unable without help to cat off the Ecar (which is great
and thick) the purulent matter remains within, and eating in from time to time, caueth a deep ulceration downwards.
Q. What danger is there of lamenes, in cae of imprudent Burning?

A. When he that performs the operation, burns the Nerves and Ligaments too hard, that may eaily occaion convulions of limbs and lamenes: Which evil yet needs not to be feared (no more than that above-mentioned,) if you employ a good Mater, or follow my precription.

div.head: CHAP. XIV.
Of the Serous wellings of the Gout, bred by accident, and the Cure of them.
div.p: Q. OF what matter do thee Swellings conit?

A. Of a Serous matter, pervaded with altnes, motly caued by accident through pain; being of little danger,
and not troubleome to cure; epecially in or about the Joynts of the limbs, in which thee aqueous tumors are very eaily bred by pain.
Q. It eems, you make no great matter of the cure of thee wellings, which yet Phyitians count very troubleome to cure, knowing that they are not to ue any repercuive means in this cae?

A. 'This erous humor cannot be better dicharged than by our way of Burning; and that is o ure and afe, that no body ever needs to apprehend from thee wellings any ill, much les incurable nodes or knots, foramuch as by our Burning the humor and other feculent matter evaporates, whereby alo the part affected is trengthned, and preerved from all putridnes.

div.head: CHAP. XV.
Of the Nodes and Stony Tumors, and their Cure.
div.p: Q. WHence aries that Stony or Chalky hard welling in the external parts?
A. From the faeces or ediment of the erous welling; as hath been taught in the Symptoms of the Gout.
Q. Is there a difference to be made between thee hard Tumors?
A. There is; for there is a great difference between a Schirrus that is hardned, unmovable and indolent, and uch an one as is but coming on, and not yet hardned.
Q. Are both thee kinds curable?
A. The firt yields to no remedies; the other is bet and oonet cured by our Burning, whereby it is fully dicharged, without any relicks remaining behind.
Q. Have you experience hereof.

A. I had a notable one in our chief
Chirurgion, Francis de Ray, a very skilful Mater, who in his Art had erv'd our Eat-India Company near 30 years. He was exceedingly tormented by the Gout, and got a Schirrhus upon the fore-part on his right hand, which though it took not quite away the Ue of the hand, yet did very much diable and weaken it by a notable intumecence; which being by my advice burnt and o opened, was in a little time perfectly cured; the matter of the Schirrus, thence dicharged, white like mixed chalk, which the Patient himelf took up with a Spatula, and having laid it on a paper, hew'd it me, being dried; whereupon his hand was o trengthned, that he could ue it at pleaure. In like manner the ame peron freed himelf from uch another imperfect Schirrus, eated upon the great Joynt of the great Toe on his left foot.
Q. When, I pray, is the bet time to perform this Burning on the head of the imperfect Schirrus?

A. Then when the Gout returns
again to the chirrous part; which very eaily comes to pas in thoe that are much ubject to the Gout; for, in following this Precript, you kill two Birds with one tone, and cure at the ame time the Gout and the Schirrus.
Q. Will not this Burning mollify and cure a perfect Schirrus?
A. I have not tried this hitherto; mean time I trut, there are means to be found, if not totally, yet in part to remove this evil.
Q. What then think you to be mot adviable in this cae?

A. To open, (as often is done and mut be done) the skin, and to take out the matter of the Schirrus as far as is poible, and that done, to heal up with my Coridons or Leaf-plaiters the skin as well as you can.
Q. But then, if this hould ucceed well, can you preerve the place thus weakned from a new afflux of humors?

A. I think, I can and that after this manner: If the Schirrus were, for example, upon the knuckle of the forefinger,
I would then duly burn the limb under it on the hand, and thereby intercept all ill humors, and o keep them from flowing to the weak part.
Q. But what, if that hould fail you, and the Gout urprie the limb with a new afflux of humors?

A. Then hould I reolve to hinder thoe humors from coagulation and induration by the advantage of our Bruning remedy; by which means you may at leat take away the difigurements, which thee nodes caue in the limbs, if you cannot retore the ue of the limbs.
Q. It eems, you have ome hopes even of the lat?

A. I have, becaue I know, that the nodes do lodg not in the very Joynts, but about them; and being dicharged one way or another, 'tis found that the Joynts are free, provided only that the veins and arteries, yea the nerves too, be not o obtructed by the bignes, hardnes and diuturnity of this tony tumor, that
the pervaion of the Blood and Animal pirits cannot by fit means be retored; in which cae the limb mut needs remain tiff.

div.head: CHAP. XVI.
Whether there be different orts of the Gout, and an Eential difference betwixt them?
div.p: Q. ARE not almot all Phyitians of opinion, that there are different kinds of the Gout, eentially diering from one another; or at leat, that there is the Cold and the Hot Gout?
A. They are; but they mitake, being miled by the external Symptoms: For, all Gout arieth from cold, dry, and malign damps.
Q. But yet the Gout may be ditinguihed?

A. It may, in divers repects, and principally, First, in repect of the Limb it eizes on; whence are the
names of Chiragra, Sciatica, Podagra, &c. Secondly, in repect of the quantity, and quality, grones or ubtilty of the Gouty matter, more or les malignity; whence proceed the denominations of the Running and Fixed, Young and Old, Adventitious and Hereditary Gout. Thirdly, in repect of the greater or les afflux of humors. Fourthly, the Gout is either with nodes, or without nodes. Fifthly, there is a Gout which is eated in or about the Joynts, and another (though that be rarely perceived) which lodges it elf in the midt of the limbs: And this is to be noted againt all thoe, who will not acknowledg uch a Gout for any Gout; which is a great mitake, and no longer tolerable, becaue Experience teacheth us otherwie.

div.head: CHAP. XVII.
Means ueful to prevent the Gout.
div.p: Q. WHat general means do you think to be good to prevent the Gout?

A. Thee following: Firt, you mut beware of windy meat and drink. Secondly, you mut avoid great and violent commotions of the mind, epecially the paion of anger. Thirdly, neither mut you put your body into too violent motions and exercies, nor afflict it with nightwakes. Fourthly, you mut take continual care to keep your body oluble, and to prevent cotivenes, nor to remove the ame too uddenly. Fifthly, 'tis beneficial, to take a gentle Vomitive after your meal, once a week. Sixthly, as oon as you perceive any igns of a Fever (the mother of the Gout,) then is it proper to take a udorifick, by the advice of ome experienced Phyitian, to open the pores,
and to promote evaporation. Eighthly, ince that many of the chief Phyitians forbid wine to Gouty perons, as if it were poion to them; (though Sennertus is not o peremptory therein, but that he allows even to thoe that actually are in a gouty fit, a cup of good and incere Rhinih wine, epecially if the Patient cannot forbear it:) I ee no reaon in the World, why thee Patients hould be o quite debarr'd this trengthning and cordial liquor, (wine,) as in and after the fit; epecially if it be a good condition'd wine. And my opinion is, that uch a wine is o far from being noxious, that it is beneficial to them, for many reaons, which Van Helmont alledgeth at large in his Book of Fevers; whoe judgment I cannot but ubcribe to in this matter.

div.head: CHAP. XVIII.
Of the Tooth-ach or the Gout of the Teeth, and the Cure thereof
div.p: Q. IS there alo a Gout of the teeth; for I have been inform'd by Dr. Wilhelmus de Ryne, who lately is arriv'd here, that there is publiht a treatie in Europe, entituled, of the Gout of the Teeth?

A. Thus is very properly expret that kind of tooth-ach, which hath the ame proximate Caue with the Gout, and arieth from cold Damps, as the Gout doth, which otherwie, according to the common opinion is bred from Deluxions.
Q. But eriouly, do you think, that the Gout and Tooth-ach come from the ame Caue?

A. Ti's certain to me (whatever ome may alledg to the contrary,) that the next caue, the part afflected, the eat, the ways, the ignes and ymptoms are the ame in thee ditempers,
and do agree together.
Q. Is then the Cure of the Tooth-ach to be perform'd after the ame manner as of the Gout?
A. By no means, the Tooth-ach is to be cured in another place, becaue that the place, where the pain hath its eat here, is within the mouth and the teeth, where you cannot come to burn with our Moxa?

Q. Would you then have the Temporal Artery open'd with a lancet, (this eeming to be the way by which the evil damp may be expelled out of the teeth;) as ome hath ventur'd to do, to the great eae of the pain?
A. This means is too dangerous, becaue it is very ubject to occaion an Aneurima, and pends too much of the vital pirits.
Q. What do you ay then of carification in the neck or upon the houlders; or of purging, or of blood-letting?
A. Thee and the like remedies eldom give eae.
Q. Would you have then the aching Tooth pulled out?

A. Not at all; that way being a deperate one, and not only accompanied with great pain & michief to the poor Patient, but alo occaioning many evils, and even death it elf. But take me right, I pray; for I here only peak of that kind of Tooth-ach, which is above decribed, not of that which comes from the Rottennes of teeth.

Q. What then, may we follow Spigelius, whole manual operation Scultetus mentions in the 18th of his Chirurgical Obervations; who with his knife, heated red-hot, did cut off that little branch of the temporal artery which runs through the Ear to the teeth; by which means the pain preently vanihed and never return'd.

A. Tis true, that Scultetus peaks with great commendation of this device, calling it a Chirurgical remedy of wonderful vertue; which the Author hath firt practied upon himelf, and afterwards, in Scultetus his preence, upon others (always with good ucces:) And this hath been further improved by others:
For whereas Spigelius made ue of a red-hot knife, to cut off the aid little branch on the outide of the Ear; others have ued a little flat cauteriing Iron, in a ilver cae, that they might go afely, and not burn deeper than was fit; and therewith they have burnt off and ear'd within the Ear, the ame ramification of the Carotid Artery, with the like happy ucces: As I my elf have experienced 26. or 28. years ago at Arnheim, where Dr. N. Coets did, by this means, immediatly free me from an intolerable tooth-ach. I have alo undertood here in India from very credible Perons, that D. Godefridus Dellius, Miniter at Kooten near Wyck of Durtede, hath cured many of that pain by this very means.
Q. Since this is o excellent and effectual a remedy, hall we then tand by it, or is there omething to be aid againt it?

A. So there is; and to deal plainly with you, it ought to yield to a better remedy, viz. to our burning with
Moxa, the which in the Gout of the Teeth erves not only for a dicharging but alo for a revulive intercepting remedy, which always produces good (if ued according to my precript) and never the leat evil. For, whereas by the former way, of uing the red-hot knife and the cautery, the body loes one of the neceary and the nobler kind of blood-veels, to the detriment and poiling of the teeth; by our way thoe veels are preerved entire and unhurt. T'is true indeed, that the pain of the teeth by the former art is o removed as that it never returns (in cae that whole branch be burnt off;) but this is alo true, that by uch a cauteriing operation there is for ever cut off that afflux of the blood and vital pirits, through this ear'd artery, to the teeth; whereupon at lat mut follow an exiccation and mortification of the teeth.
Q. Since then you prefer your burning with Moxa before all other remedies in the Tooth-ache alo, pray, teach me, where it is to be applyed?

A. Jut upon the temporal artery, where the ame in the Temples, not far from the Ear, beats tronget in a violent Tooth-ache; which is that place where Chirurgians are wont to apply their Matick-plaiters, &c.
Q. But is the burning with Moxa upon the temporal arteries not too dangerous?
A Not at all, if your work be done carefully; yea it is a means very beneficial, and hath been practied by the father Phyitians, of Hippocrates himelf.
Q. After what manner then is this Burning to be performed; mut it be done as in the cae of the Gout?

A. Jut o; only you mut in this cae Kindle leer pellets, and thee to the number of three upon one place, and no more; though it be not forbidden, at ome little ditance from the burned place to perform anew the like burnning; which may be done not only without fearing the leat michief from it, but alo with an expectation of more eae.

Q. Is this Burning followed by a
Mitigation or by a Removal of the pain?

A. It performs both, in an admirable manner, and that intantly, or preently after, without fail; unles, unknown to the Patient and Operator, the Tooth-ach hould proceed from a hidden rottennes of the Teeth.
Q. But, Sir, how will you make it out, that this is a revulive and intercepting remedy, and withal dicharging the part affected from the evil which afflicts it?

A. This is as clear as the Sun at noon-day, and that from the effects: For the Damps, which were already by the expelling power of the Heart driven out into the place that is between the membrane and the teeth, and there produced o great pain by the expanding of the enible membrane, are by this our Burning drawn back to the place where the Burning is made, and other Damps intercepted that were on the way, and o the body, according to wih, disburthen'd from both, and the blood purified.
Q. Mean time the learned Sennertus aith, that the true means duly to purge the blood hath not yet been found out: Is that true?

A. It is; for the ways hitherto found out to purify the blood do not deerve that name. For, the matter being well conidered, they do omething ele than dicharge the blood of its impurities: And I am of opinion, that unto this very time there hath been found out no better means for that purpoe than what we here propoe; foramuch as thereby the Blood is uddenly and mot afely purged of all noxious damps.
Q. What is to be done after the Burning for the Tooth-ach?
A. After this light Burning there remains only a little gray peck, which needs not to be look'd after, becaue it dries and heals up of it elf, and erves till then for a vent to the evaporating damps.

div.head: AN APPENDIX Concerning Three Remarkable OBSERVATIONS.
OBSERV. I.
About the Removal of the Falling-Sicknes by our way of Burning with Moxa.
div.p:
IAcobus Jonas, about 13 years of age, Son of Jonas Aertz, who was chief Chirurgion in the Hopital of the Noble Company in Batavia, having taken a fancy (againt his Fathers command) to ee the ad and dimal agonies of dying perons in a place where deperate and incurable perons were lodged, did upon a Sunday morning ee one of thoe give up the ghot in o affrightful a
manner under uch terrible convulions, that being more than uually terrified therewith, he could not forbear to peak of it at Table with amazement: At which relation his Father being much troubled, did everely rebuke him for o dangerous a curioity, trictly commanding him, never to repair to that place again, from an apprehenion, leat one time or other he hould rue uch a curioity. But behold! The boy laying himelf down upon a bench after dinner, to take (as 'tis common in that place) a nap in the afternoon, there appear'd to him (as he related afterwards) in a dream that fearful departure of the dead, o lively to his fancy, that in a fright he awaken'd, crying out a loud, and, eied on with a terrible fit of the Epilepy. To which ditemper he remained a great while ubject, and in uch a manner, that upon the leat diturbance he fell into new fits, of which his Father was not able by any of the means by him employed to free him.
This did o grieve the good old man, that in all likelihood it contributed not a little to his haty death.

It hapned, that upon occaion I viited the widow of this Chirurgeon, where eeing this Youth halting, I asked what the caue of it was. He hewing me a welling above his left knee, accompanied with grievous pains; I was apt to conclude that it was a Gouty ditemper, and reolved, thereupon, with the conent of the parties concerned, to treat it as uch; employing my way of burning, which I did with three pellets conumed on one place: whereupon all pain being vanihed, the youth intantly walked without any inconvenience. I put upon it a Coridons plaiter, and order'd him to renew it twice in 24 hours. And ince that time he never had any fit of the Falling-icknes; doubtles becaue that the venemous Damps, which caued this grievous ditemper, had been evaporated our of the body, or rather had been thence drawn out by the Moxa. And 'tis
obervable, that (according to the relation made me by the Lad's Mother,) this Damp never caued in him a fit of the Falling Sicknes, till it had firt for a while tormented the place above-mentioned, no otherwie as if it had been the Gout. Now, when this peccant matter did acend from the knee to the Head (which uually fell out every ixth or eighth day,) it was attended with a enible Cold in the paage of this Damp, yet acting o lowly, that the Youth had time enough to give warning to his Mother of a new it, that o he might take the better care of him.

div.head: OBSERV. II.
Concerning the Cure of a Mad Female-Slave, by the Burning with Moxa.
div.p:
URula, one of our Female-laves being ent out to buy ome fih for our family, and come to the
place where the Fiher-men ue to be with their boats, and having een one of them arrived with fih, he tept over everal of thoe boats to get into that, where he might buy. Which having done, and tepping back again over thoe boats to hore, he was frighted at the udden and unexpected ight of a drowned Humane body, he had tept over, that had been brought up to be viewed by the appointed Officer. Which fright did o eize her, that he fell down and quite fainted away. But being omewhat recovered, he was brought home with the fih in her hand, but out of her wits; which the ame night was follow'd by uch a fit of Madnes, that at firt we knew not what to do. But having recollected our elves, we reolved to end for the Guinam-Doctres, to hear her advice, ince he had o uccesfully cured me of the Gout. She came the next morning, and being well inform'd of the circumtances of this eae, and demanded whether he knew any remedy
for it, he anwer'd, That he would ue her Art, and hoped God would bles her operation. What doth he? She bids the other laves that were preent to hold this poor he-lave fat, and binds the hair of her head cloe together, into a knot; which done, he makes one of the mot robut laves to hold that hair-knot with his hand, and to turn the Patient's head which way he, (the Doctres) would have it. Whereupon he began to burn with her Moxa cloe under the hair, from the fore-part of the head unto the neck and from the neck again to the forepart, round about; performing this o artificially and gently, that hardly any mark could be perceived: Whereupon this poor mad creature, to the admiration of us all, fell into a weet leep, of which he awaken'd towards evening in very good health and in her right wits, without ever after relaping into that grievous fit of madnes again; it being now about Ten years ince her recovery.

div.head: OBSERV. III.
Touching a Strange Catalepis or Stiffnes cured by the Moxa.
div.p:
ONe of our he-laves, which my Wife had lent to our chief Chirurgion William Perant (who a little while before had married one of my daughters,) was about evening, as he was at work without doors upon the wall, uddenly urpried with this ditemper, o that in a trice he became as tiff as a tatue, without any hearing, eeing, peaking, or moving any limb. The aid Chirurgion having tried upon her the utmot of his skill to no purpoe, and I being made acquainted with the condition of this wretched lave, my Wife and Son, upon my deire, went immediately to her, and according to my direction burned her upon the Arteries of her temples: Which was no ooner done, but he recover'd the ue of her enes and the Motion of all her limbs,
and he enjoys to this very day a good tate of health.

I conclude with the advice of the never too much celebrated Nicolaus Tulpius, in the firt Book of his Medical Obervations, chap. 8. where he aith, You Chirurgions, take good notice of the wholome Ue of Cauticks; it hall turn to your Credit, and to the Benefit of your Patients.
